Event: Four out of Five US Homes now contain radios.
Significance: Listeners have access to a broader variety of music than was possible when they were mostly limited to live music produced in a small geographic area.

Event: Ampex, funded by Bing Crosby, produces the first commercial reel-to-reel tape recorder.
Significance: Reel-to-reel tape recording resulted in higher-fidelity recordings, and allowed recordings to be edited and enhanced prior to being committed to vinyl.

Event: Columbia releases the first 33 RPM long-playing 12 inch vinyl record (LP).
Significance: Another step towards higher fidelity, and allowing an artist to showcase a collection of recordings rather than a single recording.

Event: RCA Victor releases the first 7 inch 45 RPM vinyl single.
Significance: The new records were more durable and higher fidelity than the older 78 RPM records made from shellac.

Event: Seeburg introduces the first all 45 RPM vinyl record jukebox.
Significance: This advance made relatively high-fidelity popular music available in restaurants, bars and other commercial establishments.

Event: Fender Precision Bass created by Leo Fender.
Significance: The electric bass became an important instrument for almost all rock music, second in importance only to the electric guitar.

Event: Fender produces the Telecaster, a solid-body electric guitar.
Significance: This dual-pickup solid-body electric guitar allows guitarists to play more loudly and allows the guitar to become a lead instrument.

Event: Fender introduces the Stratocaster, a high-end solid-body electric guitar.
Significance: This guitar features three pickups and other improved features, and has become one of the most enduring and popular guitars used in rock music.

Event: Most home record players now capable of playing both 33 1/3 and 45 RPM records (LPs and singles).
Significance: Listeners can now enjoy at home whatever music is available on record.

Event: Throughout the mid-fifties, high fidelity (hi-fi) playback equipment becomes commercially successful.
Significance: Home listeners can now listen to music with a fidelity that rivals that of live music.
Stereo allowed much more natural sound reproduction

Event: Atlantic Records installs the first eight-track tape recorder in its studios; studios outside the US would not catch up until the mid to late sixties.
Significance: Multitrack tape recording allowed voices and instruments to be recorded on separate tracks, allowing each to be separately altered, prior to being mixed down into the final two stereo tracks. This allowed the artist to have a greater say in the overall sound of the recording as it was finally released.
These amplifiers offered more volume, allowing rock bands to play in larger halls and still be clearly heard, as well as offering a more aggressive sound.

Event: Wah-wah pedal is first used on rock recordings.
Significance: The wah-wah pedal and other effects boxes allowed a guitarist to alter the sound of his or her instrument in interesting ways.

Event: US Federal Communications Commission imposes a non-duplication rule for FM radio stations.
Significance: This new rule prevented owners of FM radio stations from broadcasting a duplication of programming already available on another AM station. Many owners responded by quickly creating music programs in which the disk jockeys were allowed to play whatever music they wanted, thus creating a radio outlet for album cuts that were otherwise too long or too "uncommercial" to have ever allowed them to be aired on radio. FM radio became a popular distribution channel for rock music, which offered increased sound quality and stereo reproduction when compared to AM radio.
